Inference: Water usage dropping sharply during rain detections, weather-based irrigation reductions, low temperatures, and high humidity indicates ideal rainfall substitution
Description: Environmental and system conditions align to minimize irrigation while rainfall fully meets moisture needs.
short rationale: Ideal rain substitution; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage remaining high during rain detections, weather-based reductions, and falling temperatures indicates delayed irrigation shutdown or override
Description: The system detects rain and reduces irrigation, but physical watering does not stop immediately.
short rationale: Delayed/override shutdown keeps usage high in rain.

Inference: Water usage increasing during no rain detections, weather-based increases, rising temperatures, and falling humidity indicates strong atmospheric drying response
Description: Heat and dry air drive irrigation to compensate for rapid moisture loss.
short rationale: Drying-driven response; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage falling during no rain detections, weather-based reductions, low temperatures, and high humidity indicates natural cooling and moisture retention
Description: Environmental conditions reduce the need for irrigation even without rainfall.
short rationale: Cooling/humidity reduce need; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during rain detections, weather-based increases, high temperatures, and low humidity indicates hot-rain evaporation overpowering rainfall benefit
Description: Rainfall evaporates quickly, forcing the system to continue irrigating.
short rationale: Hot-rain evaporation causing extra use; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling during rain detections, weather-based reductions, high temperatures, and high humidity indicates storm-like conditions with high atmospheric moisture
Description: Moisture-rich conditions reduce irrigation needs despite warm temperatures.
short rationale: Storm moisture suppresses use; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stable during fluctuating temperature/humidity, variable rain detections, and alternating irrigation logs indicates schedule-dominant irrigation logic
Description: The system follows fixed patterns regardless of environmental variations.
short rationale: Schedule-dominant behavior; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage rising sharply after rain detections when temperatures rise and humidity falls indicates rapid post-rain drying
Description: Soil quickly loses moisture after storms, prompting increased irrigation.
short rationale: Rapid post-rain drying drives high use.

Inference: Water usage dropping after rain detections when temperatures fall and humidity rises indicates prolonged post-rain moisture retention
Description: Cool, moist conditions maintain hydration, allowing irrigation reduction.
short rationale: Post-rain retention lowers use; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high humidity and rain detections with low water usage indicate efficient storm-response behavior
Description: The system reduces irrigation because rain and humidity already provide moisture.
short rationale: Efficient storm response; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during falling humidity, rising temperatures, no rain detections, and rising water usage indicate accurate dry-season onset detection
Description: Environmental indicators collectively point to escalating dryness.
short rationale: Dry-season onset detection; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during moderate rain detections, stable temperatures, and rising humidity with minimal water usage indicate light but adequate rainfall
Description: Rain provides just enough moisture to justify cutting irrigation.
short rationale: Light adequate rain; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during high humidity, rising temperatures, no rain detections, and rising water usage suggest tropical evapotranspiration patterns
Description: Humidity alone cannot offset moisture loss in hot climates, requiring irrigation boosts.
short rationale: Tropical-like stress prompting irrigation; low risk.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during rain detections with water usage remaining high and temperatures stable indicate misaligned irrigation scheduling
Description: Automatic watering cycles overlap poorly with rainfall timing.
short rationale: Misaligned schedule keeps usage high during rain.

Inference: Water usage rising during no rain detections, weather-based increases, low temperatures, and falling humidity suggests dryness driven by atmospheric desaturation
Description: Even in cool conditions, dry air accelerates water loss.
short rationale: Dry-air desaturation driving use; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling during no rain detections, weather-based reductions, high temperatures, and rising humidity indicates humidity-driven irrigation suppression
Description: Moist air reduces evaporation, enabling lower irrigation even in warm conditions.
short rationale: Humidity-driven suppression; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stabilizing at moderate levels during alternating rain detections and fluctuating weather logs indicates balanced mid-season moisture control
Description: Neither rainfall nor irrigation dominates, but both contribute to maintaining equilibrium.
short rationale: Balanced mid-season control; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases with falling humidity, stable temperatures, no rain detections, and stable water usage indicate irrigation scaling limits
Description: The system calls for more irrigation, but actual output does not increase.
short rationale: Scaling limits cap output despite commands.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions with rising humidity, stable temperatures, intermittent rain detections, and stable water usage indicate environmental moisture saturating irrigation demand
Description: Humidity and light rainfall reduce the need for more irrigation without requiring major system adjustments.
short rationale: Environmental moisture saturates demand; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during rain detections, weather-based increases, high temperatures, and falling humidity indicates severe storm evaporation
Description: Rainfall evaporates mid-air or on soil surface, producing insufficient hydration and requiring irrigation support.
short rationale: Severe evaporation during storms; low sensitivity.
